chargeHist.descr: 1st Degree Child Sex Assault - Sexual Contact with Person under Age of 13

result.execSummary:
The defendant Robert C Stryker was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • 1st Degree Child Sex Assault - Sexual Contact with Person under Age of 13, a class B felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.02(1)(e).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Defendant IS NOT eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program and the Substance Abuse Program.  Attorney to submit a letter for jail credit.
*Sentence credit of 4 days is granted.

superMiscConds.notes: Bail applied to Costs/DNA Surcharge.  Paid in full.  Remainder of bail to be refunded to poster.

Prohibited contact with any child under the age of 16.
Prohibited contact with the Miller Family.
Contact with his own children per the Family court case.
Register as a sex offender.
Computer / Internet access to be monitored and controlled by Agent.
Photo equipment to be determined by Agent.
Sex offender treatment.
Follow through with any treatment and/or counseling recommended by Agent.
  Defendant to provide DNA sample, if not yet provided, immediately if in custody otherwise within (3) business days at the Waukesha County Sheriff Department.
  If Probation/Extended Supervision is revoked and/or a prison term ordered, outstanding financial obligations shall be collected pursuant to statutory provisions, including deductions from inmate prison monies.  If discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collections may include income assignment.

Letter from defendant to the Court requesting a review of the sentence credit listed in the amended judgments of conviction in his cases.
**Reviewed by Judge Dorow on 10/12/2022 - Upon review, it does appear the defendant is entitled to an additional day of credit (so 4 total days in this case, 15CF985). An Amended JOC will be prepared forthwith. No action is needed in 14CF985.**

Motion for Sentence Credit and for an Amended Judgment of Conviction with attached cover letter filed by defendant.

**Reviewed by Judge Dorow on 08/16/22--The Court will grant the request for 3 days jail credit unless the State objects in writing by August 29, 2022. If an objection is filed the Court will hold a hearing. clerk to advise the parties.**

**Reviewed by Judge Dorow on 08/31/22--No objection has been filed by the State.  An amended Judgment of Conviction is to be prepared.**

LF 8/31--sent to Case.
IT IS ORDERED AND ADJUDGED by this court in an opinion filed on December 29, 2021, that: Judgment and order affirmed
IT IS ORDERED that the petition for review is denied, without costs.

IT IS ORDERED that the motion to provide supplemental authorities is granted; and IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the plaintiff-respondent, State of Wisconsin, is directed to serve and file a response to the petition for review on or before March 30, 2022.
Copy of letter from defendant to Sheila T. Reiff, Clerk of Supreme Court. - Forwarded to Appellate Court electronically 1/19/22.

IT IS ORDERED that the motion is denied. The 30-day period in which to file a petition for review may not be enlarged. First Wisconsin National Bank of Madison v. Nicholaou 87 Wis. 2d 360, 274 N.W. 2d 704 (1979); and
IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the motion itself shall be deemed a timely, but non-conforming petition for review. However a statement in support of the petition, conforming to the requirements of Wis Stat. 809.62(2) and (4), must be filed with the clerk of this court by February 25, 2022. If the statement is not filed by that time, this petition will be summarily dismissed.

records.addlTxt:
Defendant Robert C Stryker in court with attorney Anthony D Cotton.  Michael Thurston appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  State makes recommendations.  Defendant's father makes statements.  Attorney Cotton makes statements.  Defendant makes statements.  Court makes statements/oral ruling. Attorney Cotton to submit jail credit by written letter. 

The Court Orders the Following:  Count #1

Imposed Sentence of:

16 Years Imprisonment (Credit - TBD)

8 Years of Initial Confinement

8 Years of Extended Supervision

Conditions of Extended Supervision:

Follow through with any treatment and/or counseling recommended by Agent;

Register as a sex offender.

Prohibited contact with any child under the age of 16.

Prohibited contact with the Miller family. 

Contact with his own children per the family court case.

Computer / internet access to be monitored and controlled by agent.

Photo equitment to be determined by agent.

Sex offender treatment.  

Cost: $268.00  Bail to be applied
 
DNA surcharge: $ 250.00 Bail to be applied

DNA Sample ordered and to be provided immediately if in custody or within (3) business days at the Waukesha County Sheriff Department. 

Defendant is not eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program

Defendant is not eligible for the Substance Abuse Program

Felony warnings, immigration warnings, voting rights and firearms warnings given.
Sentencing hearing on December 19, 2016 at 03:00 pm.

Case called for day 3 of the jury trial.  Defendant Robert C Stryker in court with attorney Anthony D Cotton.  Michael Thurston appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court goes over jury instructions prepared with the parties.  Jurors arrive to the courtroom at 9:08 am.  Court reads jury instructions.  State gives closing arguments.  Defense gives closing arguments.  State gives rebuttal closing arguments.  Court reads jury instruction.  Bailiff sworn in.  Deliberations begin at 10:25 am.  Court addresses the parties outside of the jurors.  Attorney Cotton moves for a mistrial.  Court denies the request for a mistrial.  Jury comes back with a verdict at 1:10 pm.  Court reconvenes at 1:17 pm.  Jury returns to the courtroom at 1:19 pm.  Court reads the verdict as follow:  Count #1:  GUILTY.  Court polls the jurors.  Court speaks the the jurors on the record.  Jurors excused at 1:22 pm.  State moves for a judgment of conviction.  Defense moves to dismiss.  Court makes statements.  Court enters judgment on the verdict and finds the defendant guilty.  State moves to have the defendant remanded into custody.  Attorney Cotton objects and moves to have sentencing on the same date as the defendant's other case.  Parties continue with statements.  Court makes statements.  Court will allow the defendant to continue out on bail.  Court schedules this case for sentencing.

Case called at 8:34 am for day 2 of the jury trial. Defendant Robert C Stryker in court with attorney Anthony D Cotton.  Michael Thurston appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court addresses witnesses to be called today.  Court is waiting on a juror #18.  Court called the juror's home phone number and left a message.  Court tried to call the juror's work, to no avail.  Parties make statements, wish to move on with the trial without juror #18.  Shortly afterwards, the juror called the jury coordinator.  Court moves forward without juror #18, but the court orders the juror to send in a written letter to the court regarding her nonappearance and will possibly be ordered to appear before the court on another date.  

State calls witness Officer Ashley M. Dewart, sworn in, testified.  Court takes a short recess. 
Court reconvenes at 10:03 am.  Court addresses the future witnesses and video.  Jury returns to the courtroom at 10:05 am.  State calls witness Detective Paula Hoffa, sworn in, testified.  Court excuses the jury for lunch, to return at 12:30 pm.

Court reconvenes at 12:34 pm.  ADA Thurston makes statements regarding a scheduling issue.  Court makes statements regarding the predicted weather for this evening.  Jury returns to the courtroom at 12:36 pm. State calls witness Amy Stryker, sworn in, testified.  Side bar called at 12:59 pm.  Testimony continues. 

State calls witness Detective Kenneth Stucker, sworn in, testified.  Jurors excused from the courtroom at 1:41 pm. Court addresses an objection to a question without the jury present.  Court takes a short recess.  Court reconvenes at 1:50 pm.  Court addresses side bar called at 12:59 pm.  Jury returns to the courtroom at 1:52 pm.  Testimony continues.  ADA Thurston moves for a sidebar, court denies request.  State has no additional witnesses.  State rests.  Court excuses the jury from the courtroom.  Attorney Cotton moves for dismissal of this case.  State objects to dismissal.  Court denies the defense' motion to dismiss.  Court questions the defendant regarding his right to testify.  Court takes a recess.  

Court reconvenes at 2:23 pm.  Court conducts colloquy with the next witness.  Jury returns at 2:30 pm.  Defense calls witness Ashlee Thomas, sworn in, testified.  State calls a sidebar at 2:43 pm.  Testimony continues. Defense calls witness Sara Flayter, sworn in, testified.  Defense shows two DVD testimonies of minor children to the jury.  Testimony of Sara Flayter continues.  Sidebar called at 4:01 pm.  Testimony continues.  Defense rests.  Court excuses the jurors for the evening.  Court addresses sidebars taken.  Court takes a short recess.

Court reconvenes at 4:30 pm.  Court goes over jury instructions with the parties.  Case to resume at 8:30 am on 12/15/2016.
by the court, to the jurors.
Juror's selection and peremptory challenges filed.
Voir dire list and random list filed.

Defendant Robert C Stryker in court with attorney Anthony D Cotton.  Michael Thurston appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court goes over potential witnesses for the trial.  Court goes over initial jury procedures with the parties.  Court addresses the use of an interpreter during trial.  Court addresses preliminary jury instructions.  Attorney Cotton makes statements regarding certain public present in the courtroom.  Court makes ruling on the request by the defense and denies the request.  

Court calls for the jury at 8:57 am.  Jury arrive at 9:16 am.  23 potential jurors seated in the jury box.  All potential jurors sworn in.  Court goes over introductions with the jury.  Court reads initial jury instruction.  Court begins voir dire.  Court strikes juror #23 from the jury box for cause.  Court calls juror #24 to the jury box, voir dire continues.  Court strikes Juror #14 for cause.  Court calls juror #25 to the jury box.  Court takes a short recess at 10:29 am.  

Court reconvenes at 10:53 am.  Voir dire continues.  Court strikes juror #4 for cause.  Court calls juror #26 to the jury box, voir dire continues.  Court will take 3 jurors outside of the public hearing and conduct voir dire in a private location due to a sensitive voir dire question.  Parties resume in the private location at 11:08 am.  Attorney Cotton moves to object to media being present.  Court cannot close the hearing to the media.  Private voir dire with juror #17 held.  State moves to strike juror for cause.  Court grants request.  Private voir dire with juror #19 held.  Defense moves to strike juror for cause.  Court denies request.  Private voir dire with juror #24 held.  No motions.  Court and parties return to the courtroom at 11:25 am.  Court excuses juror #17 for cause.  Juror #27 called to the jury box, voir dire continues.  Side bar called at 11:37 am.  Voir dire continues.  Side bar called at 11:42 am.  Peremptory strikes begin at 11:43 am.  13 jurors selected.  Court addresses jurors selected with instructions.  13 jurors sworn in.  Jurors excused for the lunch break, to return at 1:00 pm.  

Court addresses the sidebars called.  Court addresses the request of the sign language interpreter.  Attorney Cotton moves for exclusion of witnesses.  Court will exclude all witnesses.  

Case reconvenes at 1:02 pm.  Court addresses the State's request to address the victim's ability to communicate.  Court questions the victim's mother.  Attorney Cotton makes statements regarding the exclusion order and advises the court he will be calling the victim's mother for testimony.  Attorney Cotton addresses a statement made and actions taken over the lunch recess by the public.  Attorney Cotton moves for a mistrial.  ADA Thurston makes statements but does not feel the actions taken are mistrial grounds. Court will not grant a mistrial at this time, but shares concerns on the record.  State advises the court that the interpreters wish to speak with the court.  Court denies the request at this time.  

All 13 jurors return to the courtroom at 1:18 pm.  Court reads opening jury instructions.  State begins opening statements.  Defense gives opening statements.  State calls witness M.M., sworn in, testified.  Cross examination by Attorney Cotton.  Redirect by Attorney Thurston.  Court takes a short recess.  

Court reconvenes at 2:35 pm.  Jury returns to the jury box at 2:36 pm.  State calls witness C. Miller, sworn in, testified.   Cross examination by Attorney Cotton.  Exhibit 1 is marked, offered and received.  Sidebar held. 
Cross examination continues.  Court takes a short recess at 3:45.  Court takes up matters outside of the jury's presence and places the side bar on the record.  Attorney Cotton moves for a mistrial and argues his motion. Attorney Thurston argues against the motion for mistrial.  Court denies the motion for mistrial at this time for reasons stated on the record. 

Court reconvenes at 3:56 p.m.  Witness C. Miller remains on the witness stand.  Attorney Thurston conducts cross-examination of the witness.  
Witness is excused and released.

State calls witness N.M., sworn in, testified.   Cross examination by Attorney Cotton.  Exhibit 2 is marked, offered and received. 
Witness is excused and released.

Jury excused for the evening at 4:32 p.m.  Jury to report to jury room at 8:30 a.m. on Wednesday, December 14, 2016.
Defendant Robert C Stryker in court with attorney Anthony D Cotton.   District Attorney's Office Law Intern appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Matter remains on for jury trial.

Defendant Robert C Stryker in court with attorney Anthony D Cotton.  Michael Thurston appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  ADA Thurston makes statements, withdrawing motion as stated on the record.   Gregory Martin sworn in, testified. Parties give closing arguments.  Court makes oral ruling.  Court will not allow Gregory Martin to testify at the trial.  Court grants this motion.

Mr. Stryker is also allowed to use a computer during his 12-step group, Celebrate Recovery, for purposes of helping the group set up the pre-prepared Power Point presentation that is used on a weekly basis.)  :  02-25-16 Court approves use of computer for purpose of completing 2015 income tax return while supervised by Lawrence Stryker.  Court will allow the defendant to use a computer at work for work related purposes only, during work hours only.  Defendant is not to have any visual recording devices of any type, no cameras. Defendant may have contact with Amy S. for purpose of sale of home, child visition, and divorce proceedings. Not use any digital or video recording devices. No unsupervised contact with anyone under the age of 18 and no contact with any victim listed in criminal complaint.  NO access to the internet or use of computers except at a public library or the Department of Work force Development.  Any viewing of pornography of any kind is strictly prohibited.

Cases 15CF985, 14CF1068, and 16CF576 called for a hearing / bail motion hearing.  Defendant Robert C Stryker in court with attorney Anthony D Cotton.  Michael Thurston appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court addresses that it was brought up at the last hearing that a sign language interpreter is needed for this case during trial.  Parties make statements.  Court orders the State to fill out the appropriate documents if they are needed regarding the interpreter.  Attorney Thurston advises they will have an answer by Next Thursday.  Attorney Cotton moves to have the Court retain another interpreter to be able to tell them what the first interpreter is saying to the victim.  Court denies this request.  If the defense wishes to have another interpreter, they need to hire one themselves.  Parties address how a sign language interpreter works in the courtroom.  Court schedules the jury trial in case #15CF985.  Court schedules the jury trial in case #16CF576.  Court schedules sentencing in 14CF1068.  Parties address the motion for bail modification.  COURT MODIFIED THE CONDITIONS OF BAIL AS FOLLOWS:  (9/22/2016: Court grants the request to allow the defendant to use a digital camera, at work, only for work purposes, only on the grounds of Wisconsin Precision Casting.  Mr. Stryker is also allowed to use a computer during his 12-step group, Celebrate Recovery, for purposes of helping the group set up the pre-prepared Power Point presentation that is used on a weekly basis.)

Court is required/obligated to provide an interpreter if requested.

COURT MODIFIED THE CONDITIONS OF BAIL AS FOLLOWS:  02-25-16 Court approves use of computer for purpose of completing 2015 income tax return while supervised by Lawrence Stryker.  Court will allow the defendant to use a computer at work for work related purposes only, during work hours only.  Defendant is not to have any visual recording devices of any type, no cameras. Defendant may have contact with Amy S. for purpose of sale of home, child visition, and divorce proceedings. Not use any digital or video recording devices. No unsupervised contact with anyone under the age of 18 and no contact with any victim listed in criminal complaint.  NO access to the internet or use of computers except at a public library or the Department of Work force Development.  Any viewing of pornography of any kind is strictly prohibited.
